TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant was born in DATE and currently lives in GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant , together with her husband , acquired a specially protected tenancy ( stanarsko pravo ) of a flat in GPE . After her husband ’s death in DATE the applicant became the sole holder of the specially protected tenancy .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG came into force . It regulated the sale of publicly owned flats previously let under a specially protected tenancy .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant went to visit her daughter who lived in GPE . She intended to stay with her daughter for DATE . The applicant locked the flat in GPE and left all her furniture and personal belongings in it . She asked a neighbour to pay the bills in her absence and to take care of the flat .

CARDINAL . NORP However , by DATE armed conflict had escalated in GPE , resulting in severe travel difficulties in that area , including the town of GPE . From DATE , the town of GPE was exposed to constant shelling and the supply of electricity and water was disrupted for DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant submitted that in DATE the NORP authorities had stopped paying her war widow ’s pension and that the payments had resumed in DATE . The ORG submitted that the applicant ’s pension had been paid by ORG in GPE rather than ORG and that it was the GPE authorities which had stopped paying the pension in DATE .
CARDINAL . According to the applicant , she also lost the right to medical insurance . The ORG maintained that her medical insurance had never been stopped or interrupted .
CARDINAL . Given these circumstances , the applicant decided to remain in GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a certain PERSON , with his wife and CARDINAL children , broke into and occupied the applicant ’s flat in GPE . The applicant claimed that PERSON had been assisted by an official of the municipality who had provided him with a list of empty flats in GPE , including hers .

CARDINAL . On DATE GPE ) brought a civil action against the applicant before ORG ( PERSON ) for termination of her specially protected tenancy on the ground that she had been absent from the flat for DATE without justified reason , contrary to section CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . In her submissions to the domestic court , the applicant explained that she had been forced to stay with her daughter in GPE from DATE until DATE . She had not been able to return to ORG since she had no means of subsistence and no medical insurance and was in poor health . Furthermore , during her stay in GPE she had learned from her neighbour that PERSON had broken into her flat with his family . When she had enquired about her flat and her possessions in it , PERSON had threatened her over the telephone .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG terminated the applicant ’s specially protected tenancy . The court found that the applicant had left GPE on DATE and had not returned until DATE . It stated that during the relevant period the citizens of ORG had not been ordered to evacuate the town on account of the escalation of the armed conflict and that each citizen had had the choice to leave the town or to stay . On that basis the court found that the war in GPE could not justify the applicant ’s absence .

CARDINAL . NORP The court did not accept the applicant ’s explanation that she had fallen ill during her stay in GPE and had been unable to travel . It was established that she had suffered from spinal arthrosis and diffuse osteoporosis for a long time . However , this had not affected her ability to travel . Even though her left shoulder had been dislocated on DATE , she had been able to travel following the immobilisation of the injured joint . Furthermore , by DATE she had already been absent from the flat for DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s further explanation that she had stopped receiving her pension in DATE and thus had been left without any means of subsistence was not accepted by the court as a justified reason for not returning to ORG . It took the view that the applicant ’s daughter could have sent her money . Therefore , the court concluded that the applicant ’s reasons for not having lived in the flat were not justified .
CARDINAL . Following an appeal by the applicant , the judgment was quashed by ORG ( Županijski sud u ORG ) on DATE .

ORG found that the court of first instance had not given due consideration to the applicant ’s personal circumstances , namely her age and poor health and the fact that she had lost her pension and lived alone in GPE . Furthermore , the applicant ’s decision to prolong her stay in GPE should have been carefully assessed against the background of the circumstances at the material time , namely that ORG had been exposed to DATE shelling and had not had a regular supply of water or electricity , and that third parties had occupied the applicant ’s flat .
The case was remitted to the first - instance court .

CARDINAL . In the resumed proceedings , on DATE ORG again ruled in favour of the municipality and terminated the applicant ’s specially protected tenancy . It observed that she had been absent from the flat for DATE without justified reason and repeated in substance the findings of the judgment of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG reversed the first - instance judgment and dismissed the municipality ’s claim . It found that the escalation of the war and the applicant ’s personal circumstances justified her absence from the flat .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE lodged an appeal on points of law ( revizija ) with ORG ( PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG allowed the appeal , reversed ORG judgment and upheld the judgment of ORG . It found that the reasons submitted by the applicant for her absence from the flat were not justified . The relevant part of ORG judgment read as follows :

“ During the aggression against GPE , living conditions were the same for all citizens of GPE and , as rightly submitted by the plaintiff , it is neither possible nor legitimate to separate the defendant ’s case from the context of that aggression . To hold the contrary would mean assessing her case in isolation from all of the circumstances which characterised that time and determined the conduct of each individual .

Contrary to the appellate court , this ORG , assessing in that context the defendant ’s decision not to return to ORG during the aggression but to stay in GPE , considers the non - use of the flat unjustified . The factual findings made in the case reveal that , in view of her state of health and the available travel connections , the defendant was able to come to GPE ; her health would not have deteriorated because of her stay in GPE ; and she could have taken care of herself . The assumption that she would have had to make a considerable mental and physical effort in order to provide for her basic living needs ( all the citizens of GPE who remained in the town , from the youngest to the oldest , were exposed to the same living conditions ) does not justify her failure to return to GPE and , accordingly , does not constitute a justified reason for the non - use of the flat . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with ORG ( Ustavni sud PERSON ) . She claimed that her rights to respect for her home and property had been violated and that she had been deprived of her right to a fair hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Convention came into force in respect of GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s constitutional complaint . It found that ORG had correctly applied the relevant legal provisions to the facts established by the lower courts when holding that the applicant ’s absence from the flat for DATE had been unjustified . ORG concluded that the applicant ’s constitutional rights had not been violated .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the DATE LAW ( Ustav PERSON , ORG nos . DATE and CARDINAL ) , as in force at the material time , read as follows :
“ Rights and freedoms may be restricted only by law to protect the rights and freedoms of others , the legal order , public morals or health . ”
“ CARDINAL . The home is inviolable . ”
“ CARDINAL . The right to property is guaranteed .
CARDINAL . Property implies duties . Holders of the title to property and property users shall have a duty to contribute to the general welfare . ”
“ CARDINAL . Only certain provisions of a statute may have retroactive effects . ”

“ International agreements concluded and ratified in accordance with the LAW and made public shall be part of the Republic ’s internal legal order and shall be [ hierarchically ] superior to the [ domestic ] statutes . ”

CARDINAL . The relevant part of LAW on LAW ( Ustavni zakon o PERSON , ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , as in force at the material time , provided that individuals or legal entities could lodge a constitutional complaint with ORG if they considered that a judicial or administrative decision , or a decision of a legal entity invested with public authority , had violated their human rights or fundamental freedoms guaranteed by LAW ( section CARDINAL ) . A constitutional complaint , in principle , did not suspend the implementation of the impugned decision ( section CARDINAL ) . If ORG allowed a constitutional complaint , it had to quash the impugned decision and remit the case to the competent authority for a new decision ( section DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The Act on Ratification of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and Protocols Nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and DATE to the Convention ( Zakon o potvrđivanju GPE za zaštitu ljudskih prava i temeljnih sloboda i Protokola br . CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , CARDINAL i CARDINAL uz GPE za zaštitu ljudskih prava i temeljnih sloboda , ORG , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) came into force on DATE . It incorporated the ORG as an international treaty into the NORP legal system .

CARDINAL . LAW ( Zakon o stambenim odnosima , ORG nos . DATE , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , as in force at the material time , provided that a holder of a specially protected tenancy ( “ the tenant ” ) had a right to permanent use of the flat for living purposes , to sublet part of it to someone else and to participate in the administration of the building in which the flat was located . The LAW also provided that , in agreement with the provider of the flat , the tenant could exchange it for another flat and , exceptionally , use part of it for business purposes .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that the tenant ’s cohabitants could acquire the tenancy after the tenant ’s death .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL read as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) A specially protected tenancy may be terminated if the tenant ... ceases to occupy the flat for an uninterrupted period exceeding DATE .

( CARDINAL ) A specially protected tenancy shall not be terminated under the provisions of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of this section in respect of a person who does not use the flat on account of undergoing medical treatment , performance of military service or other justified reasons . ”

CARDINAL . NORP Under section CARDINAL ) the provider of the flat had to bring a civil action in order to terminate the specially protected tenancy . The tenancy was terminated as soon as the court ’s judgment , upholding the claim of the provider of the flat , became res judicata ( see , inter alia , ORG decision no . CARDINAL of DATE ) .
CARDINAL . In decisions ORG . Rev-CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE , NORP of DATE and Rev-CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE , ORG interpreted section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW as follows :
“ War events per se , without any particular reasons rendering use of the flat impossible , do not constitute a justified reason for not using it . ”

CARDINAL . In a series of decisions ( for example , in cases nos . CARDINAL of DATE , ORG - CARDINAL of DATE , CARDINAL of DATE , Rev-CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE and CARDINAL of DATE ) , starting with decision no . Rev-CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , ORG interpreted another aspect of section CARDINAL ) of LAW as follows :

“ The fact that a flat that is not being used by its tenant is illegally occupied by a third person does not , per se , make the non - use [ of the flat by the tenant ] justified . In other words , if the tenant fails to take the appropriate steps to regain possession of the flat within the statutory time - limits set forth in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ... , then the [ illegal occupation of the flat by a third person ] is not an obstacle to the termination of the specially protected tenancy . ”

CARDINAL . The Specially Protected Tenancies ( Sale to Occupier ) Act ( Zakon o prodaji stanova na kojima postoji stanarsko pravo , Official Gazette no . CARDINAL ) , as in force at the material time , entitled the holder of a specially protected tenancy of a publicly owned flat to purchase it from the provider under favourable conditions .

CARDINAL . LAW ( Zakon o parničnom postupku , ORG nos . CARDINAL and DATE ) , as in force at the material time , provided that an appeal on points of law ( revizija ) lay to ORG against second - instance judgments .

In cases where a first - instance judgment had been reversed by the second - instance judgment but ORG reversed the latter and upheld the former , the first - instance judgment became res judicata when ORG delivered its decision .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW on LAW of DATE ( “ the Vienna Convention ” ) provides :

“ Unless a different intention appears from the treaty or is otherwise established , its provisions do not bind a party in relation to any act or fact which took place or any situation which ceased to exist before DATE of the entry into force of the treaty with respect to that party . ”

CARDINAL . The Permanent Court of International Justice ( ORG ) has dealt with the issue of its jurisdiction ratione temporis in several cases . In the case of Phosphates in GPE ( Preliminary Objections ) between GPE and GPE , ORG maintained , inter alia , that the dispossession of certain NORP nationals resulting from the decision of ORG of DATE , and the denial of justice that had followed , were inconsistent with international obligations incumbent on GPE . The ratification of the declaration by which GPE accepted the compulsory jurisdiction of the ORG was filed on DATE . In its judgment of DATE ( ORG , Series A / B , no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL ) , when examining GPE ’s preliminary objection based on the lack of jurisdiction ratione temporis , the ORG held :

“ The NORP Government bases its objection on the following passage in its declaration : ‘ ... in any disputes which may arise after the ratification of the present declaration with regard to situations or facts subsequent to this ratification.’ [ p. CARDINAL ]

[ The ORG ’s compulsory jurisdiction ] only exists within the limits within which it has been accepted . In this case , the terms on which the objection ratione temporis submitted by ORG is founded , are perfectly clear : the only situations or facts falling under the compulsory jurisdiction are those which are subsequent to the ratification and with regard to which the dispute arose , that is to say , those which must be considered as being the source of the dispute . [ p. CARDINAL ]

... The situations and the facts which form the subject of the limitation ratione temporis have to be considered from the point of view both of their date in relation to the date of ratification and of their connection with the birth of the dispute . Situations or facts subsequent to the ratification could serve to found the ORG ’s compulsory jurisdiction only if it was with regard to them that the dispute arose . [ p. CARDINAL ]

[ The ] decision of ORG , owing to its date , falls outside the ORG ’s jurisdiction . ORG has sought to avert this consequence by arguing ... that the decision of DATE constituted only an uncompleted violation of international law ; that this violation only became definitive as a result of certain acts subsequent to the crucial date and of the final refusal to remedy in any way the situation created in DATE , and that these acts gave rise to the dispute between the CARDINAL Governments . [ p. CARDINAL ]

The ORG can not regard the denial of justice alleged by ORG as a factor giving rise to the present dispute . In its ORG , ORG has represented the decision of ORG as an unlawful international act ... That being so , it is in this decision that we should look for the violation of international law – a definitive act which would , by itself , directly involve international responsibility . This act being attributable to the ORG and described as contrary to the treaty right of another ORG , international responsibility would be established immediately as between GPE . In these circumstances the alleged denial of justice ... merely results in allowing the unlawful act to subsist . It exercises no influence either on the accomplishment of the act or on the responsibility ensuing from it . [ p. CARDINAL ]

... [ T]he complaint of a denial of justice can not be separated from the criticism which ORG directs against the decision of ORG of DATE , for ORG could not regard the denial of justice as established unless it had first satisfied itself as to the existence of the rights of the private citizens alleged to have been refused judicial protection . But the ORG could not reach such a conclusion without calling in question the decision of ORG of DATE . It follows that an examination of the justice of this complaint could not be undertaken without extending the ORG ’s jurisdiction to a fact which , by reason of its date , is not subject thereto .

In conclusion , the ORG finds that the dispute submitted to it by ORG ... did not arise with regard to situations or facts subsequent to the ratification of the acceptance by GPE of the compulsory jurisdiction , and that in consequence it has no jurisdiction to adjudicate on this dispute . [ pp . CARDINAL ] ”

CARDINAL . The issue of temporal jurisdiction arose also in a number of cases before ORG ( ICJ ) . In Certain Property ( GPE v. GPE ) , Preliminary Objections , GPE maintained that certain decisions by NORP courts delivered in the period DATE declaring inadmissible the action of PERSON of GPE for restitution of a painting , which had been confiscated by GPE on DATE under “ the Beneš Decrees ” , were in breach of international law . In these inadmissibility decisions the NORP courts relied on the Convention on the Settlement of Matters Arising out of the War and the Occupation , signed in DATE , as amended in DATE , which had come into force on CARDINAL DATE ( “ the Settlement Convention ” ) . In order to found the jurisdiction of the ICJ , GPE relied in its LAW DATE , which came into force between GPE and GPE on DATE . In its judgment of DATE , when examining GPE ’s preliminary objection based on the lack of jurisdiction ratione temporis , the ICJ held :

“ CARDINAL . The ORG will now consider whether the present dispute has its source or real cause in the facts or situations which occurred in DATE in GPE and , particularly , in the decisions by the NORP courts in the PERSON Painting case , or whether its source or real cause is the PERSON Decrees under which the painting was confiscated and ORG which the NORP courts invoked as ground for declaring themselves without jurisdiction to hear that case .

CARDINAL . The ORG observes that it is not contested that the present dispute was triggered by the decisions of the NORP courts in the aforementioned case . This conclusion does not , however , dispose of the question the ORG is called upon to decide , for under LAW , the critical issue is not the date when the dispute arose , but the date of the facts or situations in relation to which the dispute arose .

CARDINAL . ... The Court ... finds that the decisions of the NORP courts in the PERSON van Laer Painting case can not be separated from ORG and the Beneš Decrees , and that these decisions can not consequently be considered as the source or real cause of the dispute between GPE and GPE .

CARDINAL . The ORG concludes that , although these proceedings were instituted by GPE as a result of decisions by NORP courts regarding a painting by PERSON van Laer , these events have their source in specific measures taken by GPE in DATE , which led to the confiscation of property owned by some GPE nationals , including Prince PERSON of GPE , as well as in the special regime created by ORG . The decisions of the NORP courts in DATE dismissing the claim filed by Prince PERSON of GPE for the return of the painting to him were taken on the basis of LAW , of ORG . While these decisions triggered the dispute between GPE and GPE , the source or real cause of the dispute is to be found in ORG and the ORG Decrees . In light of the provisions of LAW a ) of LAW for the Peaceful Settlement of Disputes , GPE ’s ... preliminary objection must therefore be upheld . ”

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of ORG on ORG , as adopted by ORG on DATE ( for the text of ORG and Commentary , see Report of ORG on the Work of its MONEY , ORG of ORG , CARDINAL Session , Supplement no . CARDINAL ( A/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , chap . PERSON and chap . IV.E.CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL and CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) read as follows :
“ An act of a ORG does not constitute a breach of an international obligation unless the ORG is bound by the obligation in question at the time the act occurs . ”
“ CARDINAL . The breach of an international obligation by an act of a ORG not having a continuing character occurs at the moment when the act is performed , even if its effects continue .

CARDINAL . NORP The breach of an international obligation by an act of a State having a continuing character extends over the entire period during which the act continues and remains not in conformity with the international obligation .

CARDINAL . The breach of an international obligation requiring a ORG to prevent a given event occurs when the event occurs and extends over the entire period during which the event continues and remains not in conformity with that obligation . ”

DATE . On DATE , when depositing the instrument of ratification of the Convention with the Secretary General of ORG , the NORP Minister for ORG made the following declarations ( contained in the instrument of ratification ) :

“ GPE recognises for an indefinite period of time , in accordance with LAW No . CARDINAL and LAW No . CARDINAL , the competence of ORG to deal with petitions addressed to the Secretary General of ORG by any person , non - governmental organisation or group of individuals claiming to be the victim of a violation of the rights set forth in the LAW and its Protocols , where the facts of the alleged violation of these rights occur after the LAW and its Protocols have come into force in respect of GPE .

GPE recognises for an indefinite period of time , in accordance with LAW , LAW No . CARDINAL and LAW No . CARDINAL , as compulsory ipso facto and without special agreement the jurisdiction of ORG in all matters concerning the interpretation and application of the LAW and its Protocols and relating to facts occurring after the LAW and its Protocols have come into force in respect of GPE . ”
